reviewText: Five basically obnoxious 20-somethings go off on a weekend outing.Driver decides to take backroads "to save time."Car breaks down in front of deserted motel with a dark history.Sound familiar?NO TELL MOTEL doesn't really break any new ground in this tired genre.  The acting, direction, technical aspects are average and the ending just doesn't make sense.Filmmakers need to get together and come up with fresh innovative ideas to avoid losing horror fans.  NO TELL MOTEL is not one of those films.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The film has a rather smart plot, but poor execution. The beginning of the film shows us little Angela (Rileigh Chalmers) getting hit by a truck some years ago. A group of young adults are forced to stay at the abandoned motel where her parents lived and the incident took place. There isn't much character build up prior to them getting to this point.The motel, as you may have guessed, is haunted and has its secrets as do the young adults. The film reminded me of "Seven Deadly Sins" where guests succumb to their own device based on their sin. In this film the secret possessed by each character is reflective of an aspect of the live of the demised owners, which in turn plays a role in their fate. Yes, very clever indeed except in spite of that, the film just doesn't grab you. The production misses on the mediocre acting, bad direction, and lack of clever dialouge.The film does teach us lessons in life such as: Don't play in the middle of the road or don't take pills out of a dirty commode. Not a keeper, and should be a long way down on any rental list. I overrated the film due to the smartness of the plot.Parental Guide: F-bomb, sex. No nudity. Chalie Howes in panties.
summary: GROW A PAIR. IT WILL BE FUN
Title: N/A

reviewText: The characters are unrealistic and unlikeable, there are no scares, little gore and virtually no story.  At least the movie looks half decent and the story does get better as time passes, but after the first half hour, it's hard for this thing to salvage any kind of decency.  Worth a look if you, some friends, and some beer are into torment. But if you want a better horror movie from 2012 that features something coming back to life after being hit by a car, watch Frankenweenie.
summary: I'd Rather Stay At The Bates Hotel
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great horror / thriller film with great storyline and acting. 3 couples going on a trip when there RV crashes and they are left to stay at a abandoned motel for the night. All of the characters have secrets and they slowly reveal them. the story of the motel owners and their family was very believable and the little girl haunting the couples was really well crafted. watching this film you have to keep tabs on what is going on and the last part of the film brings everything into focus. the acting by some of the male characters was totally unbelievable with them forgetting stuff just to get a quick fix. the main actress was quite cute and had a great sexy figure... just wish she could have shown more skin or sexy outfits. as with most newer horror films the really cute actresses are killed off early while the male audience wishes to see them in some wild love making tryst with demons or ghosts. The really cute gal in this film gets hit by a car and sadly doesn't have a larger part in the film. the last scene of the main actress getting hit by a truck is dumbfounding. Am waiting for a later release that is perhaps longer that may have deleted scenes or scenes that may explain some continuity problems. overall a great film for guys and gals.. sure to keep you on the edge of your seat.
